title: Eagle Container Co., LLC v. County of Newberry
description: After careful review of Newberry County Zoning Ordinances, this Court held the mere addition of the word â€œlandfillâ€ to the listing of uses permitted did not alter the use classification of a landfill as the use classification is governed by another section.  Accordingly, a landfill remains a â€œspecial exceptionâ€ use in Newberry County.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        Eagle Container
          Co., LLC, and Jeffrey Spotts, as Personal Representative of the Estate of
          Alfred D. Spotts, Respondents,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        County of Newberry, a political subdivision, and Susie
          Berry, in her capacity as Zoning Administrator of Newberry County, Petitioners.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF
APPEALS

Appeal from Newberry County
  Â James W. Johnson, Jr., Circuit Court
Judge

Opinion No. 26538
  Heard May 29, 2008 - Filed September 2,
2008Â Â  

REVERSED


  
    
      
        George
          Robert DeLoach, III, of Merritt, Flebotte, Wilson, Webb & Caruso, of Columbia; and Hardwick Stuart, Jr., of Berry Quackenbush & Stuart, of Columbia, for Petitioner.
        Thomas
          H. Pope, III, of Pope and Hudgens, of Newberry, for Respondent.
        Robert
          E. Lyon, Jr., and M. Clifton Scott, of Columbia, for Amicus Curiae South Carolina Association of Counties.
      
    
  

ACTING
  JUSTICE KITTREDGE:Â  We granted a writ of certiorari to review the court of appealsâ€™
  opinion in Eagle Container Co. v. County of Newberry, 366 S.C. 611, 622
  S.E.2d 733 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  We are called upon to construe the effect of an
  amendment to the Newberry County Zoning Ordinance.Â  The Newberry County Council
  amended the county zoning ordinance on December 11, 2002 by adding a single
  wordâ€”â€œlandfillâ€â€”to a list of uses that may be allowed in what is classified as
  R-2 Rural District.Â  It is undisputed that prior to the amendment, a landfill
  was permitted in R-2 districts only as a â€œspecial exception.â€Â  The question
  before us is whether the single-word amendment to the zoning ordinance effected
  a change in a landfill from a â€œspecial exceptionâ€ to a â€œpermitted use.â€Â  We
  hold the amendment had no effect on the proper use classification of a
  landfill.Â  A landfill remains a â€œspecial exceptionâ€ in R-2 districts.Â  We
  reverse the contrary opinion of the court of appeals.Â  
I.
Eagle
  Container owns a 328-acre tract of land in Newberry County which is zoned R-2
  Rural District.Â  On May 16, 2003, Eagle Container applied for a special
  exception to construct and operate a landfill on the property.Â  Before this
  request was acted upon, Eagle Container apparently learned of the amended
  ordinance.Â  On June 2, 2003, it applied for, and received, a permit to operate
  the proposed landfill.Â  Two days later, on June 4, 2003, a representative for Newberry County wrote Eagle Container a letter advising the permit had been issued in error
  and was being revoked.Â  The letter stated, â€œPursuant to Newberry County Zoning
  Ordinance, landfills are permitted only in R-2 [d]istricts as special
  exceptions, which require approval of the Board of Zoning Appeals after a
  hearing.Â  Consequently, I am hereby reinstating the Special Exception
  Application filed on May 16, 2003.â€[1]Â  
On June
  17, 2003, Eagle Container filed suit, contending a landfill was a â€œpermitted
  useâ€ under the ordinance and, as such, the permit should be reinstated.Â  The
  parties filed cross motions for summary judgment, each contending there were no
  genuine issues as to any material fact.Â  The circuit court granted Eagle
  Container summary judgment, ruling a landfill is a â€œpermitted useâ€ within the
  meaning of the Countyâ€™s recently amended ordinance.Â  The County appealed, and
  the court of appeals affirmed.Â  Eagle Container Co. v. County of Newberry, 366 S.C. 611, 622 S.E.2d 733 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  
II.
Because
  we are called upon to construe the meaning of an unambiguous ordinance, our
  review does not track the fact-based summary judgment review path.[2]Â  Issues
  involving the construction of ordinances are reviewed as a matter of law under
  a broader standard of review than is applied in reviewing issues of fact.Â  Sea
    Island Scenic Parkway Coalition v. Beaufort County Bd. of Adjustments &
    Appeals, 321 S.C. 548, 550, 471 S.E.2d 142, 143 (1996).Â  â€œAlthough great deference is accorded the
  decisions of those charged with interpreting and applying local zoning
  ordinances, â€˜a broader and more independent review is permitted when the issue
  concerns the construction of an ordinance.â€™â€Â  Charleston County Parks &
    Recreation Commâ€™n v. Somers, 319 S.C. 65, 67, 459 S.E.2d 841, 843 (1995)
  (internal citation omitted) (quoting Sea Island Scenic Parkway Coalition v.
    Beaufort County Bd. of Adjustments & Appeals, 316 S.C. 231, 235, 449
  S.E.2d 254, 256 (Ct. App. 1994)).Â  â€œThe determination of legislative intent is
  a matter of law.â€Â  Id.Â  
III.
We begin our analysis with the procedural history which led to the
  December 11, 2002 amendment to the Newberry County Zoning Ordinance that is at
  the center of this dispute.Â  In December 2001, Newberry County adopted Zoning
  Ordinance No. 12-24-01 to provide a comprehensive plan for land uses and
  restrictions in Newberry County.Â  Article 3 of the ordinance establishes zoning
  districts.Â  The various zoning districts were established â€œfor the purposes of
  guiding development . . . and promoting public health, safety, morals,
  convenience, order, appearance, prosperity, and general welfare . . . .â€ 
Section 301 sets forth a nonexclusive listing of what uses may be
  allowed in the respective zoning districts. When the ordinance was enacted, R-2
  Rural Districts were defined in section 301 as follows:

  R-2 districts require large parcels for uses, allow rural and
    residential uses, including manufactured homes on individual lots, agricultural
    and related uses, ranching, recreation and hunting, a variety of government
    service uses, and limited business uses.Â  

The
  ordinance provides for three classifications of uses that may be permitted:Â  a
  â€œpermitted use,â€ a â€œconditional use,â€ or a â€œspecial exception.â€Â  These terms of
  art are defined in Article 2 of
  the zoning ordinance and are applied to the specific uses in Article 5,
  specifically section 501:

  1.Â  Permitted Uses:Â  Permitted uses listed in the district
    use tables in this Division are permitted outright. 
  2.Â  Conditional Uses:Â  Conditional uses in the district use
    tables are permitted by the Zoning Administrator without further review
    upon compliance with the conditions specified in the tables.
  3. Special Exceptions:Â  Special exceptions are permitted after review and approval by the Board of Zoning Appeals upon compliance with
    the general conditions in the regulations.Â  

(Emphasis added.)Â  
The County amended section 301 on December 11, 2002 by adding â€œlandfillâ€
  as a use allowed in R-2 Rural Districts. The amendment reads:

  WHEREAS,
    Ordinance No. 12-24-01 permits various uses in R‑2 Rural Districts; and
  WHEREAS,
    landfills should be allowed in the R-2 Rural Districts.
  NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED AS FOLLOWS:
  Article 3, Section 301 is amended to add text â€œlandfillâ€ to
    the uses permitted in R-2 Rural District.Â  The text is added to the Newberry
    County Zoning Ordinance.Â  

(Last emphasis added.)Â  Â Â 
It
  is undisputed that prior to this amendment a landfill was allowed in R-2
  districts only as a â€œspecial exceptionâ€ under section 501. Â Â Section 501 sets forth the following
  conditions for approval of a landfill within R-2 districts by the Board of
  Zoning Appeals:

  (1) Approvals shall be conditioned on the applicant receiving all
    state and federal approvals; 
  (2) All uses are a minimum of 1,000 feet from adjoining property
    lines;
  (3) The use would not constitute a safety hazard or a traffic
    hazard;
  (4) The use is not detrimental to adjacent land uses in the vicinity.Â  

When Eagle Containerâ€™s post-amendment permit application was
  ultimately treated by the County as an application for a â€œspecial exception,â€
  Eagle Container filed the underlying action in circuit court seeking
  declaratory relief and mandamus.Â  Eagle Container successfully argued in the
  circuit court that the single-word amendment to section 301 changed landfills
  from a â€œspecial exceptionâ€ to a â€œpermitted use.â€Â  The court of appeals
affirmed, from which we granted a writ of certiorari.
The dispositive question is whether the Newberry County
  Council, in amending section 301, changed landfill from a â€œspecial exceptionâ€
to a â€œpermitted use.â€Â  
We proceed from the familiar premise that in the area of
  statutory construction, our role is limited to determining legislative intent
  and effectuating that intent.Â  â€œAll rules of statutory construction are
  subservient to the one that legislative intent must prevail if it can be
  reasonably discovered in the language used, and that language must be construed
in light of the intended purpose of the statute.â€Â  McClanahan v. Richland County Council, 350 S.C. 433, 438, 567 S.E.2d 240, 242 (2002).Â  
â€œ[W]ords
  in a statute must be construed in context,â€ and â€œthe meaning of particular
  terms in a statute may be ascertained by reference to words associated with
  them in the statute.â€Â  S. Mut. Church Ins. Co. v. S.C. Windstorm & Hail
    Underwriting Assâ€™n, 306 S.C. 339, 342, 412 S.E.2d 377, 379 (1991).Â  â€œThe
  language must also be read in a sense which harmonizes with its subject matter
  and accords with its general purpose.â€Â  Hitachi Data Sys. Corp. v.
    Leatherman, 309 S.C. 174, 178, 420 S.E.2d 843, 846 (1992).Â  â€œIf a
  statuteâ€™s language is plain and unambiguous and conveys a clear and definite
  meaning, there is no occasion for employing rules of statutory interpretation
  and the court has no right to look for or impose another meaning.â€Â  Miller
    v. Doe, 312 S.C. 444, 447, 441 S.E.2d 319, 321 (1994).
Both the circuit court and the court of appeals construed the
  phrase â€œuses permittedâ€ in the descriptive language of the announcement setting
  forth the amendment as unambiguously reflecting the intent of County Council to
  change the classification of a landfill in R-2 districts from a â€œspecial
  exceptionâ€ to a â€œpermitted use.â€Â  In so ruling, the courts erroneously elevated
  the significance of this prefatory, nonbinding language.Â  In any event, such a
  construction cannot withstand scrutiny, because reference to an allowed use as
  a â€œuse permittedâ€ is not the same thing as the term of art â€œpermitted use.â€[3]Â  In fact, each of the three use
  classifications (permitted, conditional and special exception) incorporates the
  term â€œpermittedâ€ by definition.Â  Referring to any allowed use as a â€œuse
  permittedâ€ sheds no light on the proper classification of the use.Â  Under the
  clear and unambiguous approach utilized by the Newberry County Zoning
  Ordinance, it is section 501, not section 301, that determines whether an
  allowed use is classified as a â€œpermitted use,â€ â€œconditional use,â€ or â€œspecial
exception.â€Â  
Moreover, neither the circuit court nor the
  court of appeals was persuaded by County Councilâ€™s failure to amend section 501
  of the ordinance, which lists a landfill as a special exception.Â  In this
  regard, the court of appeals invoked the principle of â€œlast legislative
  expressionâ€ to confer a landfill as a â€œpermitted use.â€Â  â€œUnder the â€˜last
  legislative expressionâ€™ rule, where conflicting provisions exists, the last in
  point of time or order of arrangement, prevails.â€Â  Ramsey v. County of McCormick, 306 S.C. 393, 397, 412 S.E.2d 408, 410 (1991).Â  The last
  legislative expression rule, however, â€œis purely an arbitrary rule of
  construction and is to be resorted to only when there is clearly an
  irreconcilable conflict, and all other means of interpretation have been
  exhausted.â€Â  Feldman v. S.C. Tax Commâ€™n, 203 S.C. 49, 54, 26 S.E.2d 22,
  24 (1943).Â  Here, there is no irreconcilable conflict.Â  Because Articles 3 and
  5 of the zoning ordinance serve different functions, the amendment at issue
  here creates no conflict as to the proper use classification of a landfill in a
R-2 district.
The
  court of appeals further held that â€œthe amending ordinance directly contradicts
  section 501â€™s classification of landfills thereby repealing the classification
  and obviating the need to consider the existence of the â€˜special useâ€™
  requirements.â€Â  Eagle Container, 366 S.C. at 626, 622 S.E.2d at 741.Â Â 
  From this finding, the court of appeals held that the amendment to section 301
  repealed section 501.Â  Id.Â  This was error, for the reasons noted
  above.Â  Succinctly stated, the addition of the term â€œlandfillâ€ in the listing
  of allowed uses in section 301 creates no conflict within the ordinance.Â 
  Article 3 of the zoning ordinance simply does not speak to the proper use
  classification of allowed uses within the various zoning districts; the proper
  use classification is the function of Article 5.Â  Given the different purposes
  served by Articles 3 and 5, the single-word amendment to section 301 may be
  easily reconciled with the balance of the ordinance, specifically including
  Article 5 and section 501.Â  See, e.g., Capco of Summerville, Inc. v.
    J.H. Gayle Constr. Co., 368 S.C. 137, 141-42, 628 S.E.2d 38, 41 (2006)
  (â€œRepeal by implication is disfavored, and is found only when two statutes are
  incapable of any reasonable reconcilement.Â  Moreover, the repugnancy must be
  plain, and if the two provisions can be construed so that both can stand, a court shall so construe
them.â€ (internal citation omitted)).
IV.
We
  readily acknowledge this statutory construction dispute was fostered by the
  actions of Newberry County, especially the initial granting of Eagle
  Containerâ€™s permit application.Â  Nevertheless, well established principles of
statutory construction dictate the result we reach today.
In sum, the Article 3, section 301, listing of uses permitted
  has no bearing on the proper use classification of an allowed use as a
  â€œpermitted use,â€ a â€œconditional use,â€ or a â€œspecial exception.â€ We hold the
  mere addition of the word â€œlandfillâ€ to the listing in section 301 of uses
  permitted did not alter the use classification of a landfill.Â  Use
  classification is governed by Article 5, and accordingly, a landfill remains a
â€œspecial exceptionâ€ use in R-2 districts.
REVERSED.
TOAL,
C.J., MOORE, PLEICONES and BEATTY, JJ., concur.


[1]Â 
  The record on appeal does not contain the â€œSpecial Exception Application filed
  on May 16, 2003.â€Â  It is undisputed that the County revoked the permit approval
on the basis that a landfill is a â€œspecial exceptionâ€ in the R-2 District. 
[2]Â  When reviewing a fact-based grant of summary
  judgment, an appellate court applies the same standard applied by the trial
  court pursuant to Rule 56(c), SCRCP.Â  Englert, Inc. v. LeafGuard USA, Inc.,
  377 S.C. 129, 659 S.E.2d 496 (2008).Â  Under Rule 56(c), SCRCP, summary judgment
  is appropriate when â€œthe pleadings, depositions, answers to interrogatories,
  and admissions on file, together with the affidavits, if any, show that there
  is no genuine issue as to any material fact and that the moving party is
entitled to a judgment as a matter of law.â€Â  
[3]Â  We, too, view the intent of County Council as
  unambiguous, and when we examine the purpose of Article 3 of the ordinance
  juxtaposed to Article 5, we conclude that Article 3 is not intended to
  distinguish the various classifications of uses allowed.Â  As the court of
  appeals correctly observed, â€œArticle 3 of the Zoning Ordinance establishes
  zoning districts and lists the general purposes for each zoning district. . .
  .Â  Article 5 sets forth the zoning district regulations [and] [s]ection 500
  classifies three types of uses for the zoning districts . . . .â€Â  Eagle
    Container, 366 S.C. at 617, 622 S.E.2d at 736.Â  A review of the various
  districts listed in section 301 reveals a collection of uses without regard to
  classification as permitted, conditional or special exception.Â  The proper use
  classification of allowed uses is the very function of Article 5, specifically
  section 501.Â  Moreover, were we to find an ambiguity as a result of the
  amendment to section 301, the result would not change. It is clear that the County amended the
  ordinance with full knowledge that a landfill was a â€œspecial exceptionâ€ in R-2
  Districts.Â  Prior to the passing of the amended ordinance, the Newberry County Planning/Zoning
  Director explained:

  This
    has been a source of confusion for some applicants who were interested in
    finding out what was permitted in R-2 and where in particular landfills were
    permitted.  We thought it might need to be added as a clarification
    only.   It is not adding the use to the district; the district
    already has that use as a Special Exception.  

Notably, these
  recorded statements were made at a County Council meeting during a reading of
  the amended ordinance.Â  In any event,
  were we to indulge in the fiction that the amendment to section 301 created a
  conflict within the ordinance, the ordinance itself provides the manifest
  legislative intent for the resolution of any such conflict.Â  Article 4, section
  400, of the ordinance requires â€œthe most restrictive . . . standards shall
  governâ€ in the event of a conflict among provisions.Â Â Â

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Beachfront Entertainment, Inc.
      d/b/a Bertâ€™s Bar, John Elder, Mary Lynn Sheppard, and Cole Charles, Appellants,
				v.
				Town of Sullivanâ€™s Island, Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal from Charleston County
Deadra L. Jefferson, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 26539
Heard June 25, 2008 - Filed September 8, 2008Â Â  
AFFIRMED IN PART; REVERSED IN PART


	
		
			
				Stephen P. Groves, Sr., Bradish J. Waring, and Paul A.
  Dominick, of Nexsen Pruet, LLC, of Charleston, for appellant Beachfront
  Entertainment, Inc.
				John F. Martin, of The Martin Law Firm, of Charleston, for appellants John Elder, Mary Lynn Sheppard, and Cole Charles.
				Mark C. Tanenbaum and
  John P. Algar, of Mark C. Tanenbaum, P.A.; and Frances I. Cantwell and William
  B. Regan, both of Regan and Cantwell, LLC, all of Charleston, for respondent.
				Charles W. Patrick, Jr.,
  Gregory A. Lofstead and Matthew D. Hamrick, all of Richardson, Patrick,
  Westbrook & Brickman, of Charleston, for Amicus Curiae Tobacco Control
  Legal Consortium.
			
		
	


JUSTICE MOORE:Â  This appeal
  is from a circuit court order upholding respondentâ€™s (Townâ€™s) ordinance banning
  smoking in the workplace.Â  We find the penalty provision of the ordinance
  invalid and reverse that part of the circuit courtâ€™s decision.
FACTS

	Townâ€™s Ordinance Â§ 14-29 provides
  in essential part:
	(D) Prohibition
  of Smoking in the Workplace
	(1)Â  The employer shall provide a smoke
  free environment for all employees working in all Work Space, Work Spaces and
  Work Places as those terms are defined herein.Â  Further, the employer and all
  employees shall prohibit any persons present in said Work Space, Work Spaces
  and Work Places from smoking tobacco products therein.

A violation is punishable by a fine of $500 and/or thirty
  days in jail.Â  
Restaurants are included in the definition of
  â€œworkplace.â€Â  Appellants are the owner of a restaurant and its employees.Â  They
  brought this action claiming the ordinance is invalid because (1) the regulation
  of smoking is preempted by State law, and (2) the ordinance criminalizes
  conduct that is legal under State law.Â  The circuit court found the ordinance
  valid and granted summary judgment to Town.Â  
ISSUES

	1.     Is the
  ordinance preempted by State law?
	2.     Is the
  ordinance unconstitutional because of the penalty it imposes?

DISCUSSION
1.Â 
  Preemption
In determining the validity of a local ordinance, the
  inquiry is twofold: did the local government have the power to enact the
  ordinance; and, if so, is the ordinance consistent with the Constitution and
  general law of this State.Â  Diamonds v. Greenville County, 325 S.C. 154,
  480 S.E.2d 718 (1997). 
Appellants claim Town did not have
  the power to enact the ordinance because the regulation of smoking is preempted
  by State law.Â  After the briefs were filed in this case, we addressed this
  argument in Foothills Brewing Concern, Inc. v. City of Greenville, Â­Â­Â­377
  S.C. 355, 660 S.E.2d 264 (2008), and concluded that State law does not
  expressly preempt the regulation of smoking by a local government.Â  Further, we
  find no implied preemption.Â  See South Carolina State Ports Auth. v.
    Jasper County, 368 S.C. 388, 629 S.E.2d 624 (2006) (under the implied
  preemption doctrine, an ordinance is preempted when the state statutory scheme
  so thoroughly and pervasively covers the subject as to occupy the entire field,
  or when the subject mandates statewide uniformity).Â Â  
Appellants also argue the regulation of indoor
  tobacco smoke is preempted by the federal Occupational Safety and Health
  Administration (OSHA) and our State Occupational Health and Safety laws, S.C.
  Code Ann. Â§ 41-15-10 et seq. (1986 and Supp. 2007).Â  Federal courts have
  declined to find OSHA preempts state law, e.g., Empire State
    Restaurant and Tavern Assoc., v. New York State, 360 F. Supp. 2d 454 (N.D.
  N.Y. 2005), and we conclude there is no federal preemption of local regulation.Â 
  Further, we find nothing in our State laws regarding workplace safety
  indicating the legislature intended to preempt the regulation of indoor tobacco
  smoke in the workplace.
2.Â  Penalty
Townâ€™s ordinance imposes a fine of $500 and/or
  thirty days in jail.Â  Appellants contend the ordinance is invalid because it
  criminalizes conduct that is not illegal under State law.Â  We agree.Â  
As we held in Foothills Brewing,
  Article VIII, Â§ 14, of our State Constitution[1] requires uniformity regarding the criminal law of this State and local
  governments may not criminalize conduct that is legal under a statewide
  criminal law.Â  See also Martin v. Condon, 324 S.C. 183, 478
  S.E.2d 272 (1996)).[2]Â 
  Here, the State has not preempted the regulation of indoor smoking; a local
  government may therefore criminalize indoor smoking, but only to the extent
  consistent with State law.Â  See City of North Charleston v. Harper,
  306 S.C. 153, 410 S.E.2d 569 (1991) (local governments may not enact ordinances
  that impose greater or lesser penalties than those established by state law).Â  Townâ€™s
  ordinance is invalid in that it imposes a criminal penalty for smoking in
  places where smoking is not illegal under State law.Â  
Town contends, however, that the offending
  provision regarding a thirty-day jail term should be severed pursuant to the ordinanceâ€™s
  severance clause and the remaining fine be construed as a civil penalty.Â  We
  disagree.Â  The fine imposed under the ordinance is $500.[3] Â A violation of the provisions of the Clean Indoor Air Act restricting indoor
  smoking is a misdemeanor punishable by a fine of $10 to $25. See S.C.
  Code Ann. Â§ 44-95-50 (2002).Â  The fine imposed by Townâ€™s ordinance is
  substantially greater than the criminal fines imposed under the Clean Indoor
  Air Act for tobacco smoking offenses and cannot be construed as simply a civil
  fine.Â  
Accordingly, we find the penalty provision of the ordinance
  unconstitutional because it conflicts with State criminal law by imposing a
  criminal penalty for conduct that is not illegal under State law.Â  The order of
  the circuit court is 
AFFIRMED IN PART; REVERSED IN PART.
TOAL, C.J., WALLER, PLEICONES and BEATTY, JJ., concur.


[1] Article VIII, Â§ 14 reads:

	In
  enacting provisions required or authorized by this article, general law
  provisions applicable to the following matters shall not be set aside . . .Â 
  (5) criminal laws and the penalties and sanctions for the transgression
  thereof; . . . .

[2]In Foothills Brewing, we examined the ordinance
  in question and concluded it did not constitute a criminal law because a
  violation of the ordinance was designated an â€œinfractionâ€ and the only penalty
  imposed was a fine.Â  In this respect, the ordinance in Foothills Brewing is different from the ordinance here which imposes a fine and/or thirty days in
  jail.Â  Foothills Brewing therefore is not dispositive on this issue. 
[3] The recent amendment of the ordinance changing the
  penalty is not before us.

2008Â Â  

AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED


  
    
      
        R.
          David Massey and E. Zachary Horton, both of Brown Massey Evans McLeod &
          Haynsworth, of Greenville, James R. Thompson, of Saint-Amand Thompson &
          Brown, of Gaffney, and William E. Winter, Jr., of Winter & Rhoden, of
          Gaffney, for Petitioner.
        Randall
          Scott Hiller, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  


CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL: This
  Court granted Petitioner Betsy M. Campbellâ€™s (Mother) petition to review a
  court of appeals decision setting aside a probate court order appointing two
  examiners to evaluate Motherâ€™s mental competency in a conservatorship
  proceeding brought by her daughter, Respondent Mary Schuyler Campbell
  (Daughter).Â  We affirm the decision of the court of appeals as modified in
  accordance with our interpretation of the statute governing the appointment of
  examiners in conservatorship proceedings. 
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Daughter
  petitioned to have herself appointed as conservator of Motherâ€™s assets before
  the probate court for Cherokee County, claiming that (1) Mother was no longer
  mentally capable of caring for herself or her assets due to dementia, and (2)
  Motherâ€™s assets were being reduced due to undue influence over Mother by her
  financial advisor William W. Brown (Brown).[1]Â 
  Mother filed an answer denying the need for the appointment of a conservator
  and arguing that if the court determined she needed a conservator, Brown had
  priority to assume the role as her attorney in fact.Â  
In April 2002, Mother listed
  Dr. John Cathcart and Dr. Preston Edwards to testify at the conservatorship
  proceeding as expert witnesses on her behalf.Â  Drs. Cathcart and Edwards were
  both lifelong personal friends of Mother, and Dr. Edwards had occasionally seen
  Mother for medical reasons over a period of nearly fifty years when Mother
  primarily resided in Gaffney. Shortly after being designated as expert
  witnesses, Mother invited each of the doctors and their wives to dinner while
  she was in Greenville on other matters.Â  Although the doctors were family
  friends of Mother, their respective social outings with her at this time were also
  for purposes of observation and evaluation of Mother as her expert witnesses.Â  The
  record reveals that Motherâ€™s counsel provided Dr. Edwards with a document
  entitled â€œOutline of Testimonyâ€ summarizing what he might be asked at trial as
  an expert witness.Â  The document was also intended to guide Dr. Edwards in his
  conversation with Mother at their dinner together, indicated by the documentâ€™s
  listing of â€œdiscussion of business or financial matters,â€ followed by the
exclamation â€œdonâ€™t ask if none!â€Â  
In August 2002, the probate
  court ordered the appointment of Drs. Cathcart and Edwards to examine Mother,
  evaluate her mental competency, and render an opinion to the probate court on
  the need for the appointment of a conservator pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-5-407
  (1987).Â  Mother does not dispute that the probate court conferred with Motherâ€™s
  counsel during the preparation of the order appointing Drs. Cathcart and
  Edwards.Â  On the other hand, Daughter was entirely unaware that the probate
  court was considering an appointment of examiners until Daughterâ€™s counsel
  received a copy of the order from Motherâ€™s counsel postmarked two days after
  the probate court had actually issued the order.Â  Daughter immediately filed a
  motion to reconsider the appointment on the grounds that Drs. Cathcart and
  Edwards were not â€œdisinterested parties.â€Â  The probate court scheduled a
hearing for October.Â  
Prior
  to the probate courtâ€™s appointment of examiners, however, arrangements had
  already been made for Drs. Cathcart and Edwards to evaluate Mother, and
  therefore, only seven days after the courtâ€™s appointment, a privately chartered
  jet flew Drs. Cathcart and Edwards, accompanied by Brown, to see Mother at her
  current residence in Florida.Â  The doctors each testified that they met with
  Motherâ€™s Florida psychiatrist, visited with Mother and Father during the
  afternoon, and flew back by the same private jet that same evening.Â  Each
  doctor was compensated $2,000.00.Â  
At
  the October hearing, the probate court determined that Â§ 62-5-407 did not
  require the appointed examiners to be disinterested and that the doctors were
  â€œwell know[n] to this Court as outstanding physicians and as qualified to act
  as the Court-appointed examiners in the matter.â€Â  Therefore, the probate court
  denied Daughterâ€™s motion to reconsider the appointment of Drs. Cathcart and
  Edwards.
At
  the same hearing, Daughter moved for recusal after the probate judge directed unfavorable
  personal comments at Daughterâ€™s counsel.Â  Daughter additionally based her
  motion for recusal on the ex parte communications with Motherâ€™s counsel prior
  to the appointment of mental health examiners.Â  The probate court denied the
  motion and proceeded to a hearing on the merits of Daughterâ€™s petition to
  appoint a conservator.Â  
The
  only evidence presented as to the merits of Daughterâ€™s petition was the
  testimony of Drs. Cathcart and Edwards.[2]Â Â 
  The doctors testified that they did not perform any medical or psychological
  examinations of Mother, however both were confident in their findings that
  Mother was competent to handle her financial affairs based on their personal
  friendship with Mother, their informal dinner with Mother in April 2002,
  communication with Motherâ€™s Florida psychiatrist, and the August 2002 visit
  with Mother in Florida.Â  The probate court therefore dismissed Daughterâ€™s
  petition for appointment of a conservator.
Daughter
  appealed the probate courtâ€™s orders to the circuit court, alleging that the
  probate court erred in (1) appointing examiners that were the product of ex
  parte communications; (2) appointing examiners that were not disinterested
  parties; (3) failing to grant Daughterâ€™s motion for recusal; and (4) finding
  Mother mentally competent.Â  The circuit court set aside the probate courtâ€™s
  order appointing the examiners, finding that Â§ 62-5-407 implicitly required
  court-appointed examiners to be disinterested, and that the probate court therefore
  abused its discretion in naming Drs. Cathcart and Edwards as examiners when
  Mother had previously designated them as expert witnesses on her behalf.Â 
  Because of the probate courtâ€™s error in this regard, the circuit court set
  aside the probate courtâ€™s order dismissing Daughterâ€™s petition to appoint a
  conservator.Â  The circuit court also found that the Cherokee County probate judge should have recused himself and therefore transferred the case to
  Spartanburg County Probate Court.
Mother
  appealed and the court of appeals affirmed the circuit courtâ€™s ruling setting
  aside the probate courtâ€™s appointment of examiners and order of dismissal.Â  In
    the Matter of Campbell, 367 S.C. 209, 625 S.E.2d 233 (Ct. App. 2006). The
  court did not address the issue of recusal, noting that Mother conceded the
  issue had been rendered moot due to the death of the probate judge during the
  pendency of the appeal.Â  Id. at 212 n.1, 625 S.E.2d at 235 n.1.Â Â  
This
  Court granted certiorari, and Mother raises the following issue for review:

  Did the
    court of appeals err in affirming the circuit courtâ€™s order setting aside the
    probate courtâ€™s orders based upon a determination that S.C. Code Ann. Â§
    62-5-407 implicitly requires that court-appointed physicians be disinterested?

STANDARD OF REVIEW
The interpretation of a statute is a
  question of law for the Court.Â  Vaughan v. McLeod Regional Med. Ctr.,
  372 S.C. 505, 509, 642 S.E.2d 744, 746 (2007).Â  An appellate court may decide
  questions of law with no particular deference to the trial court.Â  Dreher v.
    Dreher, 370 S.C. 75, 79, 634 S.E.2d 646, 648 (2006).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Petitioner
  argues that the court of appeals erred in interpreting S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  62-5-407 to implicitly require that court-appointed examiners in a
  conservatorship proceeding be disinterested and independent.Â  
The cardinal
  rule of statutory construction is to ascertain and effectuate the intent of the
  legislature.Â  Dreher, 370 S.C. at 80, 634 S.E.2d at 648.Â  To this end, the
  words of the statute must be given their plain and ordinary meaning without resorting to subtle
  or forced construction to limit or expand the statuteâ€™s operation.Â  Hitachi Data Sys. Corp. v. Leatherman, 309 S.C. 174, 178, 420 S.E.2d 843, 846
  (1992).Â  If the language of a statute is unambiguous, then the rules of statutory construction are unnecessary and the
  court may not impose another meaning.Â  Hodges v. Rainey, 341 S.C. 79,
  85, 533 S.E.2d 578, 581 (2000).Â  
Section
  62-5-407(b) provides that upon receipt of a petition for appointment of a
  conservator due to alleged mental deficiency, â€œthe court shall direct that the
  person to be protected be examined by one or more physicians designated by the
  court, preferably physicians who are not connected with any institution in
  which the person is a patient or is detained.â€
Initially,
  we find that the circuit court and the court of appeals erred in interpreting Â§
  62-5-407 to implicitly require that the court-appointed examiner be
  disinterested.Â  In drafting the provisions governing conservatorship
  proceedings, the legislature undoubtedly sought to establish a framework within
  which the probate court could exercise its discretion with the best interests
  of the allegedly incapacitated person in mind.Â  It would be inconsistent with
  the subjective theory of â€œbest interestsâ€ for the Court to find an overriding
  requirement that all examiners appointed under Â§ 62-5-407 be completely disinterested
  parties.Â  In fact, in certain instances of alleged mental incapacity, it may
  actually be preferable to seek the opinion of a treating physician who is
  familiar with the patient.Â  
This
  is not to say, however, that the court of appealsâ€™ analysis entirely misses the
  point.Â  Rather, the primary flaw in the opinion below is that it fails to
  distinguish between a â€œdisinterestedâ€ party and an â€œunbiasedâ€ party.Â  Although
  the statute does not impose a per se requirement of disinterestedness, basic
  tenets of justice in our jurisprudence dictate that the appointed examiners
  must be able to render an objective opinion.Â Â  As the court of appeals rightly
  acknowledged, the obvious purpose of the statute permitting the appointment of
  examiners â€œis to provide the probate court with a medical opinion regarding the
  personâ€™s mental capacity, and it is inherent that such an opinion come from a
  neutral physician.â€Â  Campbell, 367 S.C. at 213, 625 S.E.2d at 236.Â  The
  statuteâ€™s â€œpreferenceâ€ for the examiner to be unaffiliated with any institution
  in which the examinee is a patient lends support to the notion that the
  legislature intended for the appointed examiner to be unbiased, for presumably,
  only an unbiased examiner can render an opinion to the probate court that
  considers the best interests of the allegedly incompetent party.Â  
Accordingly,
  although the court of appeals erred in interpreting an overriding requirement
  of disinterestedness into Â§ 62-5-407, we hold that the probate court is
  nevertheless obligated to appoint neutral and objective examiners and that
  failure to do so amounts to an abuse of discretion subject to reversal on
  appeal.[3]Â  
To
  this end, we hold that the court of appeals was correct in affirming the
  setting aside of the probate courtâ€™s appointment of Drs. Cathcart and Edwards.Â 
  Mother had previously designated the doctors as expert witnesses and it is
  evident in the record that Motherâ€™s counsel had coached them as such prior to
  their evaluative meetings with Mother.Â  Mother also compensated the doctors for
  the work they performed as her expert witnesses.Â  In our view, these
  circumstances illustrate the fundamental incompatibility in assuming a dual
  role as an expert witness for a party to the litigation and as a neutral
  examiner for the court.Â  Accordingly, we
  hold that the probate court committed an abuse of discretion in appointing Drs.
  Cathcart and Edwards as examiners in the conservatorship proceeding.
Additionally, although Mother
  does not raise to this Court the issue of whether the circuit court erred in
  recusing the probate judge, we briefly address the circuit courtâ€™s ruling on
  the matter because we disagree with the court of appealsâ€™ apparent finding that
  the death of the probate judge during the pendency of the appeal rendered the
issue moot. 
In our view, the circuit
  court properly ordered the recusal of the probate judge.Â  In addition to the
  preparation of an order of appointment that we find was strongly influenced by
  ex parte contact, the probate judge expressed his own favorable opinions on Motherâ€™s
  counsel and the appointed examiners in open court, while directing disparaging
  personal remarks at Daughterâ€™s counsel.Â  These incidents, in our view, are
  manifestations of a clear bias on the part of the probate judge, and therefore,
  we hold that the circuit judge properly ordered the recusal of the probate
  judge and the transfer of the case from Cherokee County Probate Court to
Spartanburg County Probate Court.Â  
CONCLUSION
For
  the foregoing reasons, we affirm as modified the court of appealsâ€™ decision setting
  aside the probate courtâ€™s order appointing Drs. Cathcart and Edwards as
  examiners in a conservatorship proceeding.Â  Accordingly, we remand the case to
  the Spartanburg County Probate Court for further proceedings consistent with this
  opinion.
MOORE, WALLER,
PLEICONES, JJ., and Acting Justice Letitia H. Verdin, concur.


[1] Daughter brought the conservatorship proceeding with respect to both her
  parents, however, the probate courtâ€™s appointment of examiners at issue in this
  case only pertains to Mother.Â  Incidentally, Father passed away during the
pendency of this appeal.
[2] Counsel for Daughter explained to the probate court that he was not prepared to
  proceed with a hearing on the merits because the notice of hearing had given
  him the impression that the court would only be hearing Daughterâ€™s motion to
reconsider the appointment of Motherâ€™s examiners.
[3] See Parkman v. Hanna, 311 S.C. 20, 22, 426
  S.E.2d 743, 744 (1992) (â€œThe authority of the Probate Court, derived from the
  statute and precedent case law, will not be disturbed absent a clear abuse of discretion.â€). Â

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        Phyllis J.
          Lukich, Petitioner,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        George Peter
          Lukich, Respondent.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF
APPEALS

Appeal from Berkeley County
Â Wayne M. Creech, Family Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  26541
  Heard June 26, 2008 - Filed September 8,
2008Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Donald
          Bruce Clark and Margaret D. Fabri, both of Charleston, for Petitioner.
        Peter
          D. DeLuca, Jr., of DeLuca & Maucher, of Goose Creek, for Respondent.
      
    
  


JUSTICE
  PLEICONES:Â  The Court granted
  certiorari to consider a Court of Appealsâ€™ decision affirming, by a vote of
  2-1, a family court order holding that petitioner (Wife) was barred from using
  an order annulling her first marriage as a defense to respondentâ€™s (Husband #2)
  allegation that their marriage was bigamous.Â  Lukich v. Lukich, 368 S.C.
  47, 627 S.E.2d 754 (Ct. App. 2006).Â  We affirm.
FACTS
 In 1973, Wife
  married Husband #1.Â  They never lived together, but never divorced.Â  In 1985,
  Wife and Husband #2 participated in a marriage ceremony.Â  In 2002, Wife filed
  an action seeking separate support and maintenance and ancillary relief from
  Husband #2.Â  During the course of discovery, Husband #2 learned Wife had never
  been divorced from Husband #1, although she had filed but never served a
  complaint in 1973.Â  In 2003, Husband #2 filed an action seeking to declare
  their marriage void as bigamous.Â  After that action was filed, Wife filed a
  separate suit seeking an annulment of her marriage to Husband #1.Â  This case
was expedited[1] and an order granting an annulment filed October 31, 2003.Â  
Wife then filed a
  motion to dismiss Husband #2â€™s bigamy action based on the October 31, 2003,
  order granting her an annulment and declaring her first marriage void ab
    initio.Â  The family court held Wife was â€œbarred from defending against
  [Husband #2â€™s] action to void the parties [sic] marriage on the basis of the
  Order of Annulmentâ€¦,â€Â  Â Â Wife appealed, and the Court of Appeals affirmed.Â  
ISSUE

  
    
      
        Did the Court of Appeals err in affirming the family
          courtâ€™s decision that Wife could not assert her annulment to defeat Husband
          #2â€™s bigamy claim?
      
    
  

ANALYSIS
The Court of Appeals
  majority affirmed the family court, relying primarily on S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  20-1-80 (Supp. 2007), titled â€œBigamous marriage shall be void: exceptionsâ€:

  All
    marriages contracted while either of the parties has a former wife or husband
    living shall be void.Â  But this section shall not extend to a person whose husband
    or wife shall be absent for the space of five years, the one not knowing the
    other to be living during that time, not [sic] to any person who shall be
    divorced or whose first marriage shall be declared void by the sentence of a
    competent court.

We agree with the Court of
  Appeals that this statute is dispositive of Wifeâ€™s claim.Â  
Under
  the statute, since Wifeâ€™s Husband #1 was still living in 1985, her purported
  marriage to Husband #2 was void unless one of the three statutory exceptions is
  met.Â  The first exception, the five year abandonment clause is not implicated
  here, nor is the second, since Wife was not divorced from Husband #1.Â  Wife
  relies upon the third exception, which excepts from the bigamy definition an
  individual â€œwhose first marriage shall be declared void by the sentence of a
  competent court.â€
The question is
  whether the October 2003 annulment order declaring Wifeâ€™s first marriage void ab
    initio relates back so as to validate her purported 1985 marriage.Â  In
  construing a statute, we need not resort to rules of construction where the
  statuteâ€™s language is plain.Â  Tilley v. Pacesetter Corp., 355 S.C. 361,
  585 S.E.2d 292 (2003).Â  Under the statuteâ€™s terms, Wifeâ€™s â€œmarriageâ€ to Husband
  #2 was â€œvoidâ€ from the inception since at the time of that marriage she had a
  living spouse and that marriage had not been â€œdeclared void.â€Â  Â§ 20-1-80.
While
  an annulment order relates back in most senses, it does not have the ability to
  validate the bigamous second â€œmarriage.â€Â  Since there was no marriage under the
  plain terms of the statute when the ceremony between Wife and Husband #2 was
  performed in 1985, there was nothing to be â€œrevivedâ€ by the annulment order in
  2003.Â  See e.g., Day v. Day, 216 S.C. 334, 58 S.E.2d 83
  (1950) (â€œA mere marriage ceremony between a man and a woman, where one of them
  has a living wife or husband, is not a marriage at all.Â  Such a marriage is
  absolutely void, and not merely voidableâ€) [2]; Howell v. Littlefield, 211 S.C. 462, 46 S.E.2d 47 (1947) (â€œ[Husbandâ€™s]
  existing marriageâ€¦incapacitated himâ€¦to contract another marriageâ€¦.â€).Â  The
  statute speaks to the status quo at the time the marriage was contracted, and
  does not contemplate either a prospective or a retroactive perspective.Â  Any
  other construction of Â§ 20-1-80 would lead to uncertainty and chaos.
Moreover,
  under South Carolinaâ€™s current view of bigamy, the family court has
  jurisdiction to decide all ancillary matters where it annuls a marriage and
  declares it void ab initio.Â  Rodman v. Rodman, 361 S.C. 291, 604
  S.E.2d 399 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  It would be inconsistent at best to hold that a
  marriage declared void ab initio never existed for bigamy purposes, yet
  can serve as the foundation for a family courtâ€™s division of property, alimony,
  and/or child support.Â  The Court of Appeals correctly affirmed the family court
  ruling on this issue.
CONCLUSION
The
  decision of the Court of Appeals is
AFFIRMED.
TOAL,
C.J., MOORE, BEATTY, JJ., and Acting Justice Georgia V. Anderson, concur.


[1] The complaint was filed October 21, 2003, the hearing was held October 31,
2003, and the order annulling that marriage signed the same day as the hearing.
[2] Wife would distinguish Day since it involves the first exception to the
  bigamy statute rather than the third.Â  What is important about Day is not
  the exception, but rather the rule: the bigamous marriage is not a marriage at
all.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        Phyllis J.
          Wogan, individually and as Personal Representative of the Estate of James J.
          Wogan, Petitioner,
        v.
        Kenneth C.
          Kunze, M.D.; Hilton Head Gastroenterology, P.A.; Thomas P. Rzecycki, M.D.;
          Hilton Head General and Laparoscopic Surgery, P.A.; Gary W. Thomas, M.D.; and
          Gary W. Thomas M.D., P.A., Respondents.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF
APPEALS

Appeal From Beaufort County
Â Curtis L. Coltrane, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26542
  Heard May 7, 2008 - Filed September 8,
2008Â Â  

AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED


  
    
      
        Samuel
          S. Svalina and Jennifer I. Campbell, both of Svalina Law Firm, of Beaufort; and
          Timothy M. Wogan, of Hilton Head Island, for Petitioner.
        Elliott
          T. Halio and Andrew S. Halio, both of Halio & Halio, of Charleston; and
          Mary Bass Lohr and James S. Gibson, Jr., both of Howell Gibson & Hughes, of
          Beaufort, for Respondents.
        Frederick
          A. Crawford and Anthony E. Rebollo, both ofÂ  Richardson, Plowden &
          Robinson, of Columbia, for Amicus Curiae SC Association of Certified Public
          Accountants.
        Johannes
          S. Kingma and John C. Rogers, of Atlanta, and Lenna S. Kirchner, of Carlock
          Copeland Semier & Stair, of Charleston, for Amicus Curiae Abram Serotta
          & Serotta, Maddocks, Evans & Co.
      
    
  


JUSTICE
  WALLER:Â  We granted a writ of certiorari to review the Court of
  Appealsâ€™ opinion in Wogan v. Kunze, 366 S.C. 583, 623 S.E.2d 107 (Ct.
  App. 2005).Â  We affirm the grant of summary judgment in favor of Dr. Kunze, as
  modified.
FACTS
Petitionerâ€™s husband, James J. Wogan, was diagnosed
  with rectal cancer in 1997 and was treated with chemotherapy by an oncologist,
  Dr. Thomas.Â  Mr. Wogan developed a very severe case of diarrhea, resulting in
  malnutrition and dehydration, for which he was referred to Respondent, Dr.
  Kunze, a gastroenterologist.Â  A colostomy was performed to stop the diarrhea
  but did not remedy the problem.Â  Dr. Kunze placed
  Wogan on the drug Sandostatin SC, which was inserted subcutaneously
  three times a day and was not covered by Medicare.Â  Sandostatin SC stopped the diarrhea within a few days.Â  
A few weeks later, Dr. Kunze suggested Mr. Wogan try a new drug,
  Sandostatin LAR, which could be administered monthly, and was, according to
  Woganâ€™s complaint, covered by Medicare.Â  Dr. Kunze refused to pre-order the
  Sandostatin LAR and administer it in his office because he did not believe it was
  covered by Medicare unless the diarrhea was caused by the chemotherapy.Â  The
  chemotherapist, Dr. Thomas, was of the opinion that it was not covered.Â  Dr.
  Thomas also refused to prescribe and administer the medication. Dr. Kunze ultimately
  agreed to administer the Sandostatin LAR, but he required the Wogans to
  purchase the monthly doses directly from a pharmacy.Â  
The Wogans purchased Sandostatin LAR at a cost of $2000 per month
  for three months.[1] Â Neither Dr. Kunze nor Dr. Thomas would assist them with filing a Medicare
  claim.Â  Mr. Wogan died in October 2001.
Mrs. Wogan filed this action against Dr. Kunze and others,
  alleging (1) negligence based on both medical malpractice from the surgery and
  Dr. Kunzeâ€™s failure to file Medicare claims for the Sandostatin LAR; (2) breach
  of Dr. Kunzeâ€™s contract with Medicare under which it was alleged Mr. Wogan was
  a third-party beneficiary; (3) violations of the South Carolina Unfair Trade
  Practices Act (UTPA); (4) breach of fiduciary duty in failing to file the
  Medicare claim; and (5) loss of consortium.Â  
The
  trial court granted partial summary judgment to Dr. Kunze, holding Mrs. Wogan
  could not assert a state law negligence claim based on Kunzeâ€™s failure to comply
  with a federal act, where the federal act (Medicare Act) did not allow a
  private right of action.Â  The trial court further rejected Woganâ€™s breach of
  fiduciary duty claim, finding the only breaches alleged (medical malpractice
  and failure to file a claim) had been alleged in the negligence cause of
  action.Â  The Court of Appeals affirmed.[2]

ISSUES[3]

  1.Â  Did the Court
    of Appeals err in affirming the trial courtâ€™s ruling that Wogan could not
    maintain a state negligence claim against Dr. Kunze based upon his failure to
    file the Medicare claim?
   2.Â  Was summary
    judgment properly granted on the breach of fiduciary duty claim?

STANDARD OF REVIEW
When reviewing the
  grant of summary judgment, this Court applies the same standard which governs
  the trial court under Rule 56(c), SCRCP: summary judgment is proper when there
  is no genuine issue as to any material fact and the moving party is entitled to
  judgment as a matter of law.Â  Fleming v. Rose, 350 S.C. 488, 493, 567
  S.E.2d 857, 860 (2002).Â  In determining whether triable issues of fact exists,
  the evidence and all factual inferences must be viewed in the light most
  favorable to the nonmoving party.Â Â  Sauner v. Pub. Serv. Auth., 354 S.C.
  397, 404, 581 S.E.2d 161, 165 (2003).Â  If evidentiary facts are not disputed
  but the conclusions or inferences to be drawn from them are, summary judgment
  should be denied.Â  Baugus v. Wessinger, 303 S.C. 412, 415, 401 S.E.2d
  169, 171 (1991).Â  The purpose of summary judgment is to expedite disposition of
  cases which do not require the services of a fact finder.Â  George v. Fabri,
  345 S.C. 440, 548 S.E.2d 868 (2001).
1.Â  NEGLIGENCE[4]Â Â Â Â  
Wogan contends the Court of Appeals erred
  in affirming the grant of summary judgment to Dr. Kunze.Â  She asserts liability
  is based, not on a violation of the Medicare Act,[5] but upon a violation of the standard
  of care of a reasonable physician.Â  Wogan claims it was a breach of the
  standard of care for Dr. Kunze to refuse to file a Medicare claim on her
  behalf.Â  The trial court and Court of Appeals held that, inasmuch as there is
  no right of action under the Medicare Act, Wogan could not base her state law
  claim on Dr. Kunzeâ€™s failure to file such a claim.Â  We agree with the result
  reached in this case; however, we find the Court of Appealsâ€™ holding overly
  broad.
Contrary to the Court of Appealsâ€™ ruling, there are some circumstances
  in which a state law negligence claim may be maintained against a third party
  as a result of the denial of Medicare benefits.Â  The United States Supreme
  Court addressed this issue peripherally in Heckler v. Ringer, 466 U.S. 602, 615 (1984).Â  Heckler involved a suit brought by three people who were
  denied reimbursement for bilateral carotid body resection (BCBR) surgery and
  one person who declined the surgery because he was unable to pay for it.Â  They
  brought an action challenging the Secretary of Health and Human Servicesâ€™
  ruling that the surgery was neither reasonable nor necessary.Â  Although the
  case involved the issue of whether the plaintiffs could maintain suit in
  federal court, or were first required to exhaust their administrative remedies
  via review pursuant to 42 USC Â§ 405 (g) of the Medicare Act, the Supreme Court
  held â€œ[I]t seems to us that it makes no sense to construe the claims of those
  three respondents as anything more than, at bottom, a claim that they should be
  paid for their BCBR surgery.â€Â  466 U.S. at 614.Â Â  Accordingly, the Court held
  that because the plaintiffsâ€™ claims were â€œinextricably intertwinedâ€ with their
  claim for benefits, that they were required to proceed under the Medicare
  Act.Â Â  The Court recognized that there may be an exception in certain special
  cases where claims are â€œwholly collateralâ€ to a claim for benefits under the
  Act, or where there is a colorable claim that an erroneous â€œdenial of
    benefits in the early stages of the administrative process will injure them in
    a way that cannot be remedied by the later payment of benefits.â€Â  466 U.S. at 618 (emphasis supplied).Â  
An example of such an exception was demonstrated in Ardary v.
  Aetna Health Plans of California, Inc. 98 F.3d 496 (9th Cir. 1996), cert.
    denied 520 U.S. 1251 (1997).Â  There, the decedent suffered a heart attack
  and was taken to a small, rural hospital near her home, which had neither
  intensive care nor cardiac facilities.Â  The decedentâ€™s husband requested she be
  air-lifted to Loma Linda University Medical Center, a larger and better
  equipped facility, but the request was denied, and Mrs. Ardary died.Â  Ardary
  filed a wrongful death suit alleging Mrs. Ardary died because of the failure to
  authorize an airlift to Loma Linda.Â  The Ninth Circuit held the plaintiffsâ€™
  claims were state common law claims, which were not â€œinextricably intertwinedâ€
  with the denial of benefits.Â  Ardary, 498 F.3d at 500.Â  The court found
  that, â€œ[a]lthough the Ardarys . . . wrongful death complaint is predicated on
  Arrowestâ€™s failure to authorize the airlift transfer, the claims are not
  â€˜inextricably intertwinedâ€™ because the Ardarys are at bottom not seeking to
    recover benefits.â€Â  Id. (emphasis supplied).Â  But see Biometric
      Health Services v. Aetna, 903 F.2d 480 7th Cir. (1990) (party
  cannot avoid Medicare Actâ€™s jurisdictional bar simply by styling its attack as
  a claim for collateral damages instead of a challenge to the underlying denial
  of benefits; if litigants may routinely obtain judicial review of these
  decisions by recharacterizing their claims under state causes of action, the
  Medicare Actâ€™s goal of limited judicial review for a substantial number of
  claims would be severely undermined).
Heckler has been interpreted as â€œsweeping within the administrative review process only
  those claims that, at bottom, seek reimbursement or payment for medical services.â€
  Â McCall v. PacificCare of Cal., 21 P.3d 1189, 1199 (Calif.), cert
    denied 535 U.S. 951 (2001) See also Regional Medical Transport
      Inc. v. Highmark Inc., ___ F.Supp2d___, 2008 WL 872255 (E.D. Pa. 2008) (in
  assessing whether a claim falls into this category, courts must discount any
  â€œcreative pleadingâ€ which may transform Medicare disputes into mere state law
  claims, and painstakingly determine whether such claims are ultimately Medicare
  disputes).Â  
Accordingly,
  contrary to the Court of Appealsâ€™â€™ opinion, whether a state common law action
  for negligence may be maintained depends, under Heckler and subsequent
  cases, on whether or not the plaintiffâ€™s claims are, at bottom, a claim seeking
  payment of reimbursement of sums which are alleged to be covered by Medicare,
  or whether the claims are wholly independent, but nonetheless stemming from the
  failure to provide some type of Medicare service.Â  To the extent the Court of
  Appealsâ€™ opinion fails to acknowledge the possibility of a state law claim, it
  is hereby modified. 
However, we concur with the result reached by the Court of
  Appeals.Â  Although Wogan characterizes her cause of action as a state law claim
  for negligence, it is, at bottom, a claim for reimbursement of the $2000 per
  month which was expended on Sandostatin LAR prior to Mr. Woganâ€™s death.Â  Her
  claim is therefore â€œinextricably intertwinedâ€ with the refusal to file a
  Medicare claim and is therefore not cognizable on state law negligence grounds.[6]Â  The grant of summary judgment to Dr.
  Kunze is affirmed.Â  
2.Â  BREACH OF FIDUCIARY DUTY
Wogan also asserts the trial court erred
  in granting summary judgment on her claim for breach of fiduciary duty.Â  Once
  again, the underlying basis of the breach of fiduciary duty claim is that Wogan
  seeks reimbursement of the expenses she suffered by having to pay for the
  Sandostatin LAR for three months out-of-pocket.Â Â  Pursuant to Heckler and Ardary, we find Woganâ€™s claim is at bottom an attempt to
  recover monies which would otherwise have been paid by Medicare.Â  Since such a
  claim is not cognizable as an independent state negligence claim, it was
  properly dismissed.

The
  Court of Appealsâ€™ opinion is 
AFFIRMED
  AS MODIFIED.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, PLEICONES and BEATTY, JJ., concur.


[1]Â 
  The Wogans paid approximately $1,278 a month for Sandostatin SC; they paid
  approximately $2,094 a month for Sandostatin LAR.Â  
[2]Â  The claims for violation of the UTPA and breach
  of third party beneficiary contract were also dismissed, as were the claims
against Dr. Thomas.Â  No issue is raised on certiorari regarding these claims.Â  
[3]Â  In light of our holding, we need not address
Woganâ€™s remaining issue.Â  
[4]Â  The underlying medical malpractice claims remain
pending against Dr. Kunze.Â  
[5]Â 
  Wogan does not contest the fact that case law generally holds there is no
  private right or action under the Medicare Act.Â  See Brogdon v. Natâ€™l
    Healthcare Corp., 103 F.Supp.2d 1322, 1340 (N.D.Ga.2000) (Congress did not
  intend to create a private right of action when it enacted the Medicare and
  Medicaid Acts and authorized their accompanying regulations); Abner v.
    Mobile Infirmary Hospital, 149 Fed. Appx. 857 (11th Cir. 2005) (noting that
  Medicare Act does not create a private right of action for negligence); Ratmansky
    ex rel. Ratmansky v. Plymouth House Nursing Home, Inc., 2005 WL 770628
  (E.D.Pa. 2005) (Medicare Act and regulations do not create a private right of
  action against nursing home).Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
[6]Â  We agree with Woganâ€™s contention that the
  violation of a statute or regulation may, in a proper case, be used as evidence
  of negligence.Â  See e.g., Wise v. Broadway, 315 S.C. 273, 433 S.e.2d
  857 (1993); Daniels v. Bernard, 270 S.C. 51, 240 S.E.2d 518 (1978); Shearer
    v. DeShon, 240 S.C. 472, 126 S.E.2d 514 (1962) (causative violation of a
  statute constitutes negligence per se).Â  Violation of a Medicare statute could
  conceivably be used to support of a state negligence claim where the state law
  claim is not inextricably intertwined with a claim for Medicare reimbursement.Â 
  For example, in Ardary, the plaintiffs would be entitled to demonstrate
  that the defendantâ€™s failure to authorize an airlift to the regional hospital
  violated a Medicare statute or regulation, thereby causing Mrs. Ardaryâ€™s
untimely death.

description: In this case, the Court reverses the trial courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment and holds that Wausau Insurance Company did not breach its duty to defend Collins Holding Corporation.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        Collins Holding
          Corporation, Respondent,
        v.
        Wausau
          Underwriters Insurance Company and Marsh USA, Inc., Defendants,
        of whom Wausau
          Underwriters Insurance Company is the, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal from Greenville County
Â Edward W. Miller, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  26544
  Heard June 25, 2008 - Filed September 8,
2008Â  

REVERSED


  
    
      
        Evans
          T. Barnette and Susan F. Campbell, both of McCutchen Blanton Johnson &
          Barnette, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        George
          J. Kefalos, of Charleston, and Richard S. Rosen and Daniel F. Blanchard, III,
          both of Rosen Rosen & Hagood, of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  


CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL: This case is an appeal from a grant of summary judgment in favor
  of Respondent Collins Holding Corporation (â€œCollinsâ€), in which the trial court
  found that Appellant Wausau Underwriters Insurance Company (â€œInsurance Companyâ€)
  breached its duty to defend Collins.Â  Finding that Insurance Company was not
  obligated to defend Collins on the underlying claim, we reverse.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL
BACKGROUND
Collins
  is an owner, operator, and distributor of amusement devices and gambling
  machines.Â  In 1997, several parties (â€œthe Plaintiffsâ€) filed suit against
  Collins and several other defendants alleging harm caused by the then-legal
  gambling machines.Â  Collins maintained a commercial general liability and
  umbrella insurance policy with Insurance Company.Â  The policy provided that
  Insurance Company would â€œpay those sums that the insured becomes legally
  obligated to pay . . . because of â€˜bodily injury,â€™â€ only if such injury was
  caused by an occurrence, and defined an â€œoccurrenceâ€ as â€œan accident, including
  continuous or repeated exposure to substantially the same general harmful
  conditions.â€Â  Collins notified Insurance Company of the suit on June 1, 2000,
  and on June 16, 2000, Insurance Company issued a letter stating that it did not
  have a duty to defend Collins and would not indemnify Collins for any loss
  resulting from the suit since the allegation in the complaint did not create a
  potential for coverage under the policy.Â  Consequently, Collins hired private
  counsel and eventually settled the lawsuit for $500,000.[1]
Subsequently, Collins brought a declaratory judgment
  action against Insurance Company to determine whether Insurance Company
  breached its duty to defend Collins in the underlying lawsuit.Â  After reviewing
  the Plaintiffsâ€™ complaint, the trial court granted partial summary judgment in
  favor of Collins and determined that Insurance Company breached its duty to
  defend Collins in the underlying lawsuit because the Plaintiffs asserted a
  negligent misrepresentation cause of action against Collins which created the
  possibility of an accident or occurrence.Â  The trial court further found that
  Insurance Company waived any defense to coverage under the policy based on
  Collinsâ€™s untimely notice of the lawsuit because it failed to assert this
  defense to coverage in its answer.
Insurance
  Company appealed the trial courtâ€™s order, and this Court certified the case
  pursuant to Rule 204(b), SCACR.Â  Insurance Company presents the following
  issues for review:

  
    I.
    Did the trial court err in finding
  Insurance Company had a duty to defend Collins because the Plaintiffs’
  complaint did not assert an “occurrence” as defined in the insurance policy?
  
  
    II.
    Did the trial court err in ruling
  that Insurance Company waived any defense to coverage based on Collins’s
  untimely notice of the underlying lawsuit?
  

STANDARD OF
REVIEW
Summary
  judgment is appropriate where there is no genuine issue of material fact and
  it is clear the moving party is entitled to a judgment as a matter of law.Â 
  Rule 56(c), SCRCP.Â  In determining whether any triable issues of fact exist,
  the evidence and all inferences which can be reasonably drawn from the evidence
  must be viewed in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party.Â  Koester
    v. Carolina Rental Ctr., 313 S.C. 490, 493, 443 S.E.2d 392, 394 (1994).Â 

LAW/ANALYSIS
I. Duty to Defend
 Insurance Company
  argues that the trial court erred in ruling that it had a duty to defend
  Collins in the underlying lawsuit because the Plaintiffsâ€™ complaint did not
  allege an â€œoccurrence.â€Â  We agree.
In an action for a declaratory judgment, the obligation of a liability
  insurance company to defend and indemnify is determined by the allegations in
  the complaint.Â  Mfrs. and Merchants Mut. Ins. Co. v. Harvey, 330
  S.C. 152, 162, 498 S.E.2d 222, 227 (Ct. App. 1998)
  (citing R.A. Earnhardt Textile Mach. Div. Inc. v. S.C. Ins.
    Co., 277 S.C. 88, 282 S.E.2d 856 (1981)).Â  If the facts alleged in the
  complaint fail to bring a claim within the policyâ€™s coverage, the insurer has
  no duty to defend.Â  S.C. Med.
    Malpractice Liab. Ins. Joint Underwriting Assâ€™n v. Ferry, 291 S.C. 460, 463, 354 S.E.2d 378, 380 (1987).Â  In examining the complaint, a
  court must look beyond the labels describing the acts to the acts themselves
  which form the basis of the claim against the insurer. Prior v. S.C. Med. Malpractice Liab. Ins. Joint Underwriting Assâ€™n, 305
  S.C. 247, 249, 407 S.E.2d 655, 657 (Ct. App. 1991) (citing Ferry, 291 S.C. at 462, 354 S.E.2d at 379-80).Â  
We hold that
  Insurance Company did not breach its duty to defend Collins against the
  underlying lawsuit because the Plaintiffsâ€™ complaint did not allege the
  possibility of an â€œoccurrenceâ€ as defined in the policy.Â  The facts of the
  complaint asserted that Collins systematically violated South Carolina laws
  specifically enacted to protect the public from excessive gambling losses.Â  For
  example, the Plaintiffs asserted Collins exceeded the maximum daily payout
  limit of $125 and engaged in advertising schemes which fraudulently induced the
  Plaintiffs to believe that they could win â€œjackpotsâ€ in excess of the $125
  limit.Â  Additionally,Â  the Plaintiffs employed words and phrases such as:
  â€œunlawfully and fraudulently seek to induce and entice;â€ â€œengaged in
  advertising about and offering inducements . . . that are clearly and expressly
  prohibited by South Carolina law;â€ â€œracketeering activity;â€ â€œconspiring;â€
  â€œknowingly engaging;â€ and â€œknowingly conducting.â€Â  These allegations constitute
  intentional, deliberate, and illegal acts executed with the purpose of addicting
  patrons to gambling machines, and in our view, such alleged conduct cannot be
  construed as accidental in nature.Â  See Green v. U. Ins. Co. of Am., 254 S.C. 202, 205, 174 S.E.2d 400, 402 (1970)
  (defining accident as an unexpected happening or event, which
  occurs by chance and usually suddenly, with harmful result, not intended or
  designed by the person suffering the harm or hurt).Â  Therefore, we
  hold that there is no possibility of coverage under the policy and that
  Insurance Company did not violate its duty to defend.Â  
We
  further hold that the trial court erred in basing its finding of the
  possibility of coverage on the negligent misrepresentation cause of action.Â  In Manufacturer and Merchants Mutual Insurance Company v.
    Harvey, 330 S.C. 152, 498 S.E.2d 222 (Ct.
  App. 1998), the parents of children whom Norman Harvey sexually abused filed
  suit against Harvey and his wife alleging, among other things, negligent
  supervision.Â  The court of appeals looked beyond the mere label of
  â€œnegligence,â€ and determined that the underlying facts of the
  complaint did not support a cause of action for negligent conduct.Â 
  Specifically, the court found that the facts alleged that Harvey committed
  intentional acts and then incorporated the acts into the negligence cause of
  action.Â  Accordingly, the court held that Harveyâ€™s
  insurance company did not have a duty to defend.
In our
  view, this case presents a similar situation.Â  The Plaintiffs alleged eight
  causes of action including Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations
  (RICO) Act violations, fraud and deceit, South Carolina Unfair Trade Practices
  Act violations, and civil conspiracy.Â  While the complaint does state a cause
  of action for negligent misrepresentation, we must look beyond the label of
  negligence to determine if Insurance Company had a duty to defend Collins. See id. at 163, 498 S.E.2d at 228
  (holding that where a complaint mischaracterizes intentional
  conduct as negligent conduct, a court may find no duty to defend despite the
  label of negligence in the complaint).Â  Â Â To support their negligent
  misrepresentation claim, the Plaintiffs incorporated the previous facts and
  alleged Collins sold, leased, and distributed machines that were equipped in a
  manner â€œas to permit manipulationâ€ and that were configured to be used in a
  manner that violated laws expressly designed to protect the public from the
  lure of excessive gambling.Â  In our view, these allegations do
  not support a claim for negligent conduct.Â  Compare Isle of Palms Pest Control Co. v. Monticello Ins. Co., 319
  S.C. 12, 15, 459 S.E.2d 318, 319 (Ct. App.
  1994) (finding a duty to defend where the complaint alleged a negligent termite
  inspection caused property damage).Â  Therefore, because the
  negligent misrepresentation claim incorporates the same facts and does not
  allege an â€œoccurrence,â€ we hold that this cause of action did not trigger Insurance
  Companyâ€™s duty to defend.Â  
II. Waiver
Insurance Company argues that the trial
  court erred in ruling that it waived any defense based on Collinsâ€™s untimely
  notice of the underlying lawsuit.Â  In light of our holding regarding the duty
  to defend, this issue is moot, and we therefore decline to address the merits
  of this issue.Â  See Seabrook v. Knox, 369
  S.C. 191, 197, 631 S.E.2d 907, 910 (2006)
  (recognizing that this Court will not decide moot
  questions in which a judgment rendered will have no practical legal effect).
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing reasons, we reverse the trial courtâ€™s order
  granting summary judgment, and hold that Insurance Company had no duty to
  defend Collins in the underlying lawsuit.Â  
MOORE,
  WALLER and BEATTY, JJ., concur. PLEICONES, J., dissenting in a separate
  opinion.

JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â  I respectfully dissent.Â  As the majority holds,
  when considering whether an insurance company has the duty to defend, the court
  must look beyond the adjectives and labels used in the complaint to describe
  the acts to the acts themselves.Â  Prior v. S.C. Med. Malpractice Liab. Ins.
    Joint Underwriting Assâ€™n, 305 S.C. 247, 407 S.E.2d 655 (Ct. App. 1997).Â 
  Here, the circuit court judge looked beyond the labels and determined that the
  negligent misrepresentation claim gave rise to a duty to defend because he
  found the â€œfraudulent unlawful promotionâ€ which suggested players could win
  more than the daily maximum allowable by law and offered special inducements to
  gamblers, might also be characterized as â€œunintentionally unlawful.â€Â  I find
  the trial judge correctly held that the Plaintiffs alleged a negligent
  misrepresentation claim based on intentional acts that may have inadvertently
  violated the law.Â  Unlike the â€œinherently injuriousâ€ conduct in Mfr. and
    Merchants Mut. Ins. Co. v. Harvey, 330 S.C. 152, 498 S.E.2d 222 (Ct. App.
  1998), the allegations that Collins advertised, offered food and beverages, and
  extended credit to Plaintiffs to promote participation in a then legal activity
  do not allege conduct that is in all particulars illegal.
The
  facts alleged in the third amended complaint[2] support the circuit courtâ€™s conclusion that the complaint alleges an occurrence
  within the meaning of this CGL policy. E.g., Isle of Palms Pest Control v. Monticello Ins. Co., 319 S.C. 12, 459 S.E.2d 318 (Ct. App. 1995).Â 
  Moreover, I would hold that the trial court correctly held appellant waived any
  right to rely on the alleged untimeliness of respondentâ€™s notice when it failed
  to plead it.Â  While an issue not raised by the pleadings may be tried by
  consent at a summary judgment hearing, Staubes v. City of Folly Beach,
  339 S.C. 406, 529 S.E.2d 543 (2000), such was not the case here. 
I
  recognize that based solely on the assertions in the Plaintiffsâ€™ third amended complaint,
  it is unlikely that Collins, as owner/lessor of the machines, could ultimately
  be liable for negligent misrepresentation.Â  However, when determining whether
  an insurer has a duty to defend, the obligation is determined by the
  allegations in the complaint.Â  Harvey, 330 S.C. at 162, 498 S.E.2d at
  222.Â  Accordingly, I would affirm the trial courtâ€™s order granting Collins
summary judgment. 


[1] The suit was removed to federal court and the district court initially granted
  an injunction and partial summary judgment against Collins and the other
  defendants.Â  The Fourth Circuit held that the district court should have
  abstained based on the authority of Burford v. Sun Oil Co., 319
  U.S. 315 (1943), and the court therefore vacated and remanded the case to the
  district court.Â  Johnson v. Collins Entmâ€™t Co., Inc., 199 F.3d 710 (4th
  Cir. 1999).Â  The district court then certified the state law questions, which
  this Court answered.Â  Johnson v. Collins Entmâ€™t Co., Inc., 349 S.C. 613,
  564 S.E.2d 653 (2002).Â  The parties settled the suit following this Courtâ€™s
opinion.Â  
[2] Although the Plaintiffs incorporate their previously stated facts and
  allegations into their negligent misrepresentation cause of action, they also
  include six paragraphs of additional facts and allegations that specifically
pertain to negligent misrepresentation.

The Supreme Court of South Carolina
In re: Amendments to Alternative Dispute Resolution Rules, 
Appendix G, Part IV, South Carolina Appellate Court Rules

ORDER

The South Carolina Commission on Alternative Dispute Resolution has proposed several amendments to the regulations contained in Appendix G to Part IV, SCACR, which govern discipline for third party neutrals.  Specifically, the proposed changes allow for a three-member hearing panel and grant the Commission Chair the authority to appoint members of a hearing panel.  Additionally, the amendments confirm that three members of the Board of Arbitrator and Mediator Certification constitute a quorum in matters of decertification, discipline and processing of complaints.  Finally, the changes add two new subsections to Section V(D) of Appendix G, which concern access to disciplinary information, communications among parties, and immunity. 
 Pursuant to Article V, § 4, of the South Carolina Constitution, we hereby amend Appendix G to Part IV, South Carolina Appellate Court Rules, as set forth in the attachment to this Order. 
  The amendments are effective immediately. 
 IT IS SO ORDERED.


  
    
     s/Jean H. Toal                                    C.J.
              
              s/John H. Waller, Jr.                           J.
              
              s/Costa M. Pleicones                        J.
            s/Donald W. Beatty                            J.
      s/John W. Kittredge                           J.
    
  

Columbia, South Carolina
September 4, 2008

.     .     .

.     .     .

If probable cause exists and the matter cannot otherwise be resolved, the Board shall notify the Commission Chair who shall appoint three (3) members of the Commission, who have not been involved previously in the matter, as a Hearing Panel.
